p: Epidemics, referred to as waba in Unani medicine, are thought to occur if such contagion or ajsam- i -khabi th a, as they are referred to, find a place in air and water ( Sina, 1878). Zakariya Razi (865–925 CE) states in Kitab al-Mansoori (Book dedicated to Caliph Mansoor), most epidemics spread in the autumn season, especially if the preceding summer season was humid, and the wind is still ( Razi, 1991). In this context, the direction of winds is given utmost significance. As Ibn Hubal Baghdadi (1121–1213 CE) mentioned in his treatise Kitab al-Mukhtarat fil-Tib (The Book on Choice of Medicine), if southern winds are replaced by northern winds, then catarrhal illnesses will occur in abundance ( Baghdadi, 2004). Because, as stated by Razi in the 15th volume of his treatise Kitab al-Hawi (The Comprehensive Book of Medicine), southern winds are warmer while the northern winds are colder, and this change of temperature makes people more susceptible to respiratory infections ( Razi, 2008).
